title: Crime Statistics Emailed to BPD Command Staff

communications.subject: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: Crime Statistics Emailed to BPD Command Staff
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

All emails, attachments, or records of crime statistics sent to or from any of the following individuals, from January 1, 2023 to the present:

Joseph Narduzzo (joseph.narduzzo@pd.boston.gov)

Robert Ciccolo (robert.ciccolo@pd.boston.gov)

Shawn Burns (shawn.burns@pd.boston.gov)

Superintendent-In-Chief Phillip Owens

Police Commissioner Michael Cox

This request includes, but is not limited to:

Statistical summaries or compilations of crime data;

Weekly or monthly incident reports;

COMPSTAT reports or briefings;

Internal crime dashboards, charts, or spreadsheets;

Any crime data prepared for or discussed in command staff meetings;

Any related emails or documents forwarded, received, or sent by these individuals that include or attach crime statistics.

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, and is not made for commercial usage.

I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Brian McCarter

communications.subject: Police Records Request :: B001676-061725
communications.communication:
--- Please respond above this line --- 
06/18/2025 RE: PUBLIC RECORDS REQUEST of June 17, 2025, Reference # B001676-061725 Dear Brian  McCarter: The Boston Police Department has received your request for public records.  This response applies only to records that exist and are in the custody of the Department. See A Guide to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, p. 32, n.115.  It is expected that a custodian of records must use her superior knowledge of her records with respect to responses to public records requests.  950 CMR 32.04(5).  Specifically, you stated: 
To Whom It May Concern: 

Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records: 

All emails, attachments, or records of crime statistics sent to or from any of the following individuals, from January 1, 2023 to the present: 

Joseph Narduzzo (joseph.narduzzo@pd.boston.gov) 

Robert Ciccolo (robert.ciccolo@pd.boston.gov) 

Shawn Burns (shawn.burns@pd.boston.gov) 

Superintendent-In-Chief Phillip Owens 

Police Commissioner Michael Cox 

This request includes, but is not limited to: 

Statistical summaries or compilations of crime data; 

Weekly or monthly incident reports; 

COMPSTAT reports or briefings; 

Internal crime dashboards, charts, or spreadsheets; 

Any crime data prepared for or discussed in command staff meetings; 

Any related emails or documents forwarded, received, or sent by these individuals that include or attach crime statistics. 

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, and is not made for commercial usage. 

I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents. 

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not. 

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires. 

Sincerely, 

Brian McCarter 

Upload documents directly: https://accounts.muckrock.com/accounts/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.muckrock.com%2Faccounts%2Flogin%2F%3Fnext%3D%252Faccounts%252Fagency_login%252Fboston-police-department-174%252Fcrime-statistics-emailed-to-bpd-command-staff-188165%252F%253Femail%253Dshawn.williams%252540boston.gov&url_auth_token=AAAj3diGLiMEHhZ1lqStA9sjze0%3A1uRjs4%3AOZ59-9eMhU1ObY9syUBgigbNeUCfJIIoRgTGXOq0wlM Your request does not comply with the public records law because it is overly broad and vague.  The Public Records Law requires that the request provide a reasonable description of records sought.  See G.L. c. 66,  § 10(a)(i).  In Chawla , the superior court found that under the Public Records Law “the reasonable description requirement contemplates that a requesting party will identify documents or categories of documents with sufficient particularity that government employees will be able to understand exactly what they are looking for, and then make a prompt production.”  See Jaideep Chawla v. Dept. of Revenue , Suffolk Sup. No. 1784CV02087, at 2 (January 23, 2019).  The Court further indicated that “requests for documents that are articulated with very broad language that calls upon non-lawyer administrative personnel to interpret the scope of what is sought, and then make fine judgments about what documents are and are not sufficiently related to the category of materials requested, will not (emphasis added) satisfy this statutory standard.” Id. In addition to the requirement that the request identify with specificity the records sought, the requester also must act in a reasonable manner so as not to overburden the public entity with complying with the request. See Friedman v. Division of Administrative Law Appeal and Bureau of Special Education Appeals, Suffolk Sup. No. 2284CV02061-C, at 3 (February 14, 2023). Although you identify the records that you are looking for, this description does not meet the statutory standard that records be identified with sufficient particularity.  The description you provide is too broad and vague.  You are requesting “all police files associated with the arrests and investigations into Albert DeSalvo” . The Department would need to locate these records and review to determine responsiveness.  This would require administrative personnel to interpret the scope of what is sought, and then make fine judgments about what documents are and are not sufficiently related  to the category of materials requested; therefore, this request does not satisfy the statutory standard of reasonable description of records.  See Chawla, Suffolk Sup. No. 1784CV02087, at 2. In Freidman, the Court focused on the reasonableness standard contemplated throughout the Public Records Law.  The Court recognized that the reasonable description requirement is necessary under the Public Records Law because the intent of the law “was not intended to reduce government agencies to full-time investigators on behalf of requestors.” Friedman quoting Assassination Archives & Research Ctr., Inc. v. Central Intelligence Agency, 720 F. Supp. 217, 219 (D.D.C. 1989).  This request is seeking all police files relating to the arrests and investigations into Albert Desalvo from the 1950s to the present day.  This is too burdensome for the Department to meet the "reasonably describes” requirement.  In addition to reviewing the files to determine responsiveness, the Department would need to review all the records to see if there is anything that needs to be redacted under statutes such as juvenile information, arrests involving minors, Criminal Offender Record Information, or incidents related to sexual assault.  The Department will also need to review the records to see if there is any personal identifying information related to specific individuals or anything identifying potential witnesses which may need to be removed under Exemptions C and F under the Public Records Law. Your request does not comply with the Public Records Law because the request is seeking records that are articulated with broad language and it does not describe the records with sufficient particularity.  It is unclear what specific records you are requesting. Therefore, the request does not comply with the reasonable statutory standard and is burdensome on the Department.  This request will be closed. We encourage you to consider narrowing your request.  You may wish to modify or clarify your request to provide sufficient particularity, including narrowing the time period or identifying specific incidents to enable the search to be processed. In the event the City were able to determine the intended scope of your request, it is likely the City would have to provide a fee estimate given the likely volume of the potentially responsive records and the need for redaction or segregation of those records. Should you seek specific records I encourage you to visit the City's public records portal. https://bostonma.govqa.us/WEBAPP/_rs/(S(4ihmrhaxyjn0l4fkagn2d4jn))/supporthome.aspx Accordingly, this request is now closed.  You may appeal this response to the Supervisor of Records in the Office of the Secretary of the Commonwealth. G. L. c. 66, § 10A (c); G. L. c. 66, § 10(b)(ix); 950 CMR 32.08; 950 CMR 32.08(1)(h) (in petitioning the Supervisor, the requester shall provide a copy of such petition to the records access officer associated with such petition). You may also appeal to the Superior Court. 950 CMR 32.06(3)(c).

communications.subject: RE: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request #B001676-061725
communications.communication:
Dear Supervisor Arthur,

I respectfully appeal the Boston Police Department’s response to my public records request submitted on June 14, 2025, via MuckRock (Request #188165). Available publicly at https://www.muckrock.com/foi/boston-3/crime-statistics-emailed-to-bpd-command-staff-188165/ 

In summary my request sought:

> "All crime statistics emailed to any of the following individuals from Jan 1, 2023 to present:
> – Joseph Narduzzo ([joseph.narduzzo@pd.boston.gov](mailto:joseph.narduzzo@pd.boston.gov))
> – Robert Ciccolo ([robert.ciccolo@pd.boston.gov](mailto:robert.ciccolo@pd.boston.gov))
> – Shawn Burns ([shawn.burns@pd.boston.gov](mailto:shawn.burns@pd.boston.gov))
> – Superintendent-In-Chief Phillip Owens
> – Police Commissioner Michael Cox"

On June 18, 2025, BPD issued a denial that did not address my request at all. Instead, the response appears to have been copied and pasted from another matter involving a different requester and a request for records related to Albert DeSalvo. The response includes no mention of crime statistics, the named individuals, or the relevant date range.

This is not a valid response under G.L. c. 66, § 10 or 950 CMR 32.06. The Department failed to evaluate or respond to the specific records requested. As such, this constitutes a constructive denial and the entire denial is procedurally invalid. 

My request is narrow and clearly defined. It names five individuals, limits the timeframe to recent years, and seeks a specific type of communication—crime statistics. It does not seek investigatory files or undefined categories of records.

Moreover, these communications would be between high-ranking officials and concern public crime data. The public has a strong interest in how that data is shared and interpreted by leadership. This type of record is unlikely to implicate any legitimate privacy or investigative exemptions.

Given the Department’s failure to evaluate the request or acknowledge its substance in any way, I respectfully request that your office order immediate compliance. This request concerns recent communications among senior officials about crime statistics—an issue of overwhelming public interest. I intend to publish any responsive records through MuckRock so the public can better understand how crime data is shared within the Department. The failure to engage with the request or provide a lawful response only compounds the urgency of disclosure.

communications.subject: SPR25/2015 Appeal Acknowledgment
communications.communication:
Dear Records Custodian,
Please be aware, this office has received an appeal relating to your entity's response to a request for public records. Attached are further details concerning this appeal. If you have any questions or wish to provide further information relating to this matter, please contact the Public Records Division at pre@sec.state.ma.us<mailto:pre@sec.state.ma.us> or 617-727-2832.
Given that the Supervisor of Records must issue a determination within 10 business days of receipt of the appeal petition, please provide any additional information to this office as soon as possible.
Thank you,

Owen G. Meech, Esquire
Staff Attorney | Office of the Secretary of the Commonwealth
Public Records Division
One Ashburton Place, Room 1719
Boston, MA 02108
Tel: (617) 727-2832
Owen.Meech@sec.state.ma.us<mailto:Owen.Meech@sec.state.ma.us>

communications.communication:
--- Please respond above this line --- 
07/16/2025 RE: PUBLIC RECORDS REQUEST of June 17, 2025., Reference # B001676-061725; SPR25/2015 Dear Brian McCarter, This letter is the response of the Boston Police Department ("Department") to your appeal to the Supervisor of Public Records, SPR25/2015, to the Department’s April 16th response which denied the records under Exemption A of the Public Records Law.  Specifically, you requested:  
To Whom It May Concern: 

Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records: 

All emails, attachments, or records of crime statistics sent to or from any of the following individuals, from January 1, 2023 to the present: 

Joseph Narduzzo (joseph.narduzzo@pd.boston.gov) 

Robert Ciccolo (robert.ciccolo@pd.boston.gov) 

Shawn Burns (shawn.burns@pd.boston.gov) 

Superintendent-In-Chief Phillip Owens 

Police Commissioner Michael Cox 

This request includes, but is not limited to: 

Statistical summaries or compilations of crime data; 

Weekly or monthly incident reports; 

COMPSTAT reports or briefings; 

Internal crime dashboards, charts, or spreadsheets; 

Any crime data prepared for or discussed in command staff meetings; 

Any related emails or documents forwarded, received, or sent by these individuals that include or attach crime statistics. 

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, and is not made for commercial usage. 

I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents. 

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not. 

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires. 

Sincerely, 

Brian McCarter 

Upload documents directly: https://accounts.muckrock.com/accounts/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.muckrock.com%2Faccounts%2Flogin%2F%3Fnext%3D%252Faccounts%252Fagency_login%252Fboston-police-department-174%252Fcrime-statistics-emailed-to-bpd-command-staff-188165%252F%253Femail%253Dshawn.williams%252540boston.gov&url_auth_token=AAAj3diGLiMEHhZ1lqStA9sjze0%3A1uRjs4%3AOZ59-9eMhU1ObY9syUBgigbNeUCfJIIoRgTGXOq0wlM The Department provided you with a response on June 18, 2025 and denied your request.  The Department denied your request because it did not meet the requirements of particularity, specificity, or reasonableness and cited the Chawla and Friedman cases. See Jaideep Chawla v. Dept. of Revenue , Suffolk Sup. No. 1784CV02087, at 2 (January 23, 2019) and See Friedman v. Division of Administrative Law Appeal and Bureau of Special Education Appeals , Suffolk Sup. No. 2284CV02061-C, at 3 (February 14, 2023). The Department inadvertently confused your request with another request.  The Department is denying your request because it does not comply with the Public Records Law; however, the Department is revising its response and providing clarification that relates to your request herein. 
Your request does not comply with the public records law because it is overly broad and vague.  The Public Records Law requires that the request provide a reasonable description of records sought. See G.L. c. 66,  § 10(a)(i).  In Chawla , the superior court found that under the Public Records Law “the reasonable description requirement contemplates that a requesting party will identify documents or categories of documents with sufficient particularity that government employees will be able to understand exactly what they are looking for, and then make a prompt production.” See Jaideep Chawla v. Dept. of Revenue , Suffolk Sup. No. 1784CV02087, at 2 (January 23, 2019).  The Court further indicated that “requests for documents that are articulated with very broad language that calls upon non-lawyer administrative personnel to interpret the scope of what is sought, and then make fine judgments about what documents are and are not sufficiently related to the category of materials requested, will not (emphasis added) satisfy this statutory standard.” Id. In addition to the requirement that the request identify with specificity the records sought, the requester also must act in a reasonable manner so as not to overburden the public entity with complying with the request. See Friedman v. Division of Administrative Law Appeal and Bureau of Special Education Appeals , Suffolk Sup. No. 2284CV02061-C, at 3 (February 14, 2023). Although you identify the records that you are looking for, this description does not meet the statutory standard that records be identified with sufficient particularity.  The description you provide is too broad and vague.  You are requesting all emails and attachments, or records of crime statistics sent to or from certain individuals at the Department from January 1, 2023 to the present . The records that you are requesting involve the following individuals:  Joseph Narduzzo ( joseph.narduzzo@pd.boston.gov ); Robert Ciccolo ( robert.ciccolo@pd.boston.gov ); Shawn Burns ( shawn.burns@pd.boston.gov ); Superintendent-In-Chief Phillip Owens; Police Commissioner Michael Cox.  You also identify search terms in your request including “statistical summaries”, "compilations”, “crime data”, “COMPSTAT”, “crime dashboards”, “charts”, and “spreadsheets”. In an effort to locate records responsive to your request, the Department the following search: Between 2023-01-01 and 2025-06-18 Terms:("Statistical summaries" OR "compilations" OR "crime data" OR "incident reports" OR "COMPSTAT" OR "crime dashboards" OR "charts" OR "spreadsheets" OR "crime statistics") Accounts:(joseph.narduzzo@pd.boston.gov, robert.ciccolo@pd.boston.gov, shawn.burns@pd.boston.gov, phillip.owens@pd.boston.gov, michael.cox@pd.boston.gov 
This search generated 6,015 documents with a total of 54, 101 pages.  The Department would need to review all of these records to determine responsiveness.  The Department is also required to redact information that is not subject to disclosure including juvenile information, arrests involving minors, Criminal Offender Record Information, or incidents related to sexual assault.   This would require administrative personnel to interpret the scope of what is sought, and then make fine judgments about what documents are and are not sufficiently related  to the category of materials requested; therefore, this request does not satisfy the statutory standard of reasonable description of records. See Chawla , Suffolk Sup. No. 1784CV02087, at 2. In Freidman , the Court focused on the reasonableness standard contemplated throughout the Public Records Law.  The Court recognized that the reasonable description requirement is necessary under the Public Records Law because the intent of the law “was not intended to reduce government agencies to full-time investigators on behalf of requestors.” Friedman quoting Assassination Archives & Research Ctr., Inc. v. Central Intelligence Agency, 720 F. Supp. 217, 219 (D.D.C. 1989) .  The Department would need to review all  54, 101 pages to determine responsiveness and to make any required redactions.  This is too burdensome for the Department to meet the "reasonably describes” requirement.  In addition to reviewing the reports to determine responsiveness, the Department would need to review all the records to see if there is anything that needs to be redacted under statutes such as juvenile information, arrests involving minors, Criminal Offender Record Information, or incidents related to sexual assault.  The Department will also need to review the records to see if there is any personal identifying information related to specific individuals or anything identifying potential witnesses which may need to be removed under Exemptions C and F under the Public Records Law. This request does not comply with the Public Records Law because the request is seeking records that are articulated with broad language and it does not describe the record with sufficient particularity.  It is the responsibility of the Department to prevent crimes, to examine crime data, and investigate crimes and to allocate its resources in the interest of public safety.  The Department’s business is public safety and is committed to community policing to foster relationships, to build trust, and to improve the quality of life through the City of Boston.  The duty and efforts of the Department to keep the public safe would require looking into crime data, statistics, and incident reports which are part of your request.  Because of the Department’s duties and its role in public safety, a majority of its records contain the search terms that you identify or relate to the topics or categories in your request.  Therefore, it is unclear what specific records you are requesting and this request does not comply with the reasonable statutory standard and is burdensome on the Department.  This request will be closed. We encourage you to consider narrowing your request.  You may wish to modify or clarify your request to provide sufficient particularity, including narrowing the time period or identifying specific incidents or records to enable the search to be processed. You may also review incident and obtain other public safety datasets by visiting https://data.boston.gov/group/public-safety In the event the City were able to determine the intended scope of your request, it is likely the City would have to provide a fee estimate given the likely volume of the potentially responsive records and the need for redaction or segregation of those records. Should you seek specific records I encourage you to visit the City's public records portal. https://bostonma.govqa.us/WEBAPP/_rs/(S(4ihmrhaxyjn0l4fkagn2d4jn))/supporthome.aspx Accordingly, this matter is now closed. 
You may appeal the substantive nature of this response within ninety (90) days. See 950 C.M. R. 32.08(1). Sincerely, Christine O’Donnell Assistant Corporation Counsel Office of the Legal Advisor Boston Police Department 

To monitor the progress or update this request please log into the Public Records Center. communications.subject: RE: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request #B001676-061725; SPR25/2015
communications.communication:
Dear Mr. Meech and Supervisor Arthur,

I write to follow up on the open appeal SPR25/2015, regarding my June 17, 2025, public records request to the Boston Police Department (BPD), tracking number B001676-061725.

This request sought emails containing crime statistics from five named BPD command staff, covering the period from January 1, 2023 to present. The request was narrowly tailored in scope and topic.

BPD’s initial response on June 18 was a clearly mistaken denial referencing an unrelated  request to my request.  It referenced a different matter and failed to address any element of the actual records sought. This constituted a procedurally invalid response, resulting in a constructive denial.

Following my appeal, BPD submitted a new denial on July 16, citing Chawla and Friedman  to claim overbreadth and burden. However, this response was both legally untimely and substantively unsupported:

-BPD has acknowledged that a search returned 6,015 responsive records, confirming the request was specific and searchable.
-The revised denial came after the statutory 10-business-day response window and therefore cannot revive BPD’s ability to invoke new exemptions.
-The Department made no effort to assist with narrowing the request or to propose rolling production.

Additionally, the Supervisor has already rejected similar defenses in my prior appeals:

SPR25/1345 — Chawla and Friedman claims overruled; request deemed “reasonably described”
SPR25/1231 — Supervisor found that email requests with specific topics and custodians are proper and enforceable

In its July 16 denial, BPD cited Exemptions (c) and (f). These do not apply here:
Exemption (c) protects records of a personal nature, not internal communications among high-ranking officials about statistical crime stats.
Exemption (f) protects investigatory materials tied to particular law enforcement cases. The requested records — crime statistics and related summaries — are not tied to any ongoing criminal investigation.

Notably, the Department itself has previously written:
“Because of the Department’s duties and its role in public safety, a majority of its records contain the search terms that you identify or relate to the topics or categories in your request.”

This is a clear admission that the records in question go to the heart of the Department’s public mission — not confidential investigations. These are the very kinds of records the public has a right to review to evaluate police performance, accountability, and public safety outcomes.

As the Supreme Judicial Court made clear in Flatley, it is the agency’s burden to prove why each exemption applies — and general references are not enough. If the Legislature intended to exempt all police records from public disclosure, it would have said so explicitly. It did not.

The Supervisor has repeatedly upheld the public’s right to access crime data and statistical communications. BPD’s attempt to shield such records contradicts both the law and its own stated role in public safety. 

This is not an isolated incident. The Boston Police Department has previously entered into settlement agreements concerning public records compliance, including the attached agreement. Yet the Department continues to use legally baseless denials, untimely responses, and improper exemptions to delay access to core public records.

This sustained pattern of behavior raises serious concerns about whether the Department is acting in good faith, as required by G.L. c. 66, § 10(a) and 950 CMR 32.08(2). At minimum, it justifies heightened scrutiny and a clear ruling ordering immediate disclosure without further delay.

I respectfully request a ruling ordering the immediate production of responsive records.

Please don’t hesitate to contact me if any clarification is needed.

title: School Residency Fraud Documents

communications.subject: Illinois Freedom of Information Act. Request: School Residency Fraud Documents
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Illinois Freedom of Information Act., I hereby request the following records:

All documents concerning reports of residency fraud involving the family of Melinda and Jestin Squires and addresses 16178 E. Franklin Rd Ewing, IL and 14425 Rescue Church Rd, Whittingon, IL.

Documents pertaining to the request for redistricting of 16178 E. Franklin Rd Ewing, IL.

Documentation of policy for investigating reports of residency fraud.

Document showing number of fraud claims made annually and if possible broken down by adjudication status.

Records are of public interest to determine how reports of violation of residency laws are applied and enforced and whether there is equal application of the law.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Chris Webster

communications.subject: Re: Illinois Freedom of Information Act. Request: School Residency Fraud Documents
communications.communication:
Chirs,

I response to your recent FOIA request of the following, I am attaching
file records:

All documents concerning reports of residency fraud involving the family of
Melinda and Jestin Squires and addresses 16178 E. Franklin Rd Ewing, IL and
14425 Rescue Church Rd, Whittingon, IL.

There are no documents submitted reporting residency fraud with the above
names or addresses listed in our files.

Documents pertaining to the request for redistricting of 16178 E. Franklin
Rd Ewing, IL.

I have attached the petition, secretary's report, proof of publication,
Order of denial of petition request, verbatim records from the court
reporter, a letter of rehearing request from the petitioner, and a letter
of denial of rehearing from the Regional Board of School Trustees.

Documentation of policy for investigating reports of residency fraud.

There is no policy for investigating residency fraud.  Districts have
residency policies by statute.  In instances where residency is being
skirted, districts can hold residency hearings to remove those in
violation.  The Regional Superintendent of Schools is tasked with any
appeals that result from such hearings.  I have none on record.  In
instances where violations are made known to me, a phone contact is made
with the school districts for them to pursue.

Document showing number of fraud claims made annually and if possible
broken down by adjudication status.

A search of my correspondence shows 1 file on hand for a residency
complaint (letter was anonymous).   I am including that letter,  with names
redacted due to the very small nature of the district involved which would
risk the possibility of identifying the children involved.
*Matt Renaud*
*Regional Superintendent of Schools*
*Regional Office of Education #13*
*Clinton-Jefferson-Marion-Washington Counties*

title: Title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972 FOIA Logs (Department of Justice, Office of the Attorney General)

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972 FOIA Logs (Department of Justice, Office of the Attorney General)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

A copy of the log of all Freedom of Information Act request made between 2019 and 2025 that includes the term "Title IX" within reference to the Education Amendments of 1972, specifically as they refer to sexual misconduct policy. I ask that all fields — including the subject of the request, the nature and description of the request, the requester, the status of the request, the dates on which it was requested and the date of its most recent status, the tracking number assigned to the request, and the final disposition of the request — be included.

I require this data for academic research purposes, in association with the University of Maryland - College Park. The study aims to understand the recent history of the development of Title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972, from 2010 to now.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Sarah Silberman

title: Flock Safety search audits, network sharing, and general order (Tukwila Police Department)

communications.subject: Washington Public Records Act Request: Flock Safety search audits, network sharing, and general order (Tukwila Police Department)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Records related to the department’s Flock Safety system:
1. Organization Audit in Flock. 
The report should include data logged from the period of December 1, 2024, to the date this request is processed. Per Flock's documentation, the Organization Audit is available within the Insights tab and is defined as searches done within the agency.

2. Network Audit in Flock.
The report should include data logged from the period of December 1, 2024, to the date this request is processed. Per Flock's documentation, the Network Audit is available within the Insights tab and is defined as searches of the organization’s Flock network by any agency in the Flock System.

3. A list of network share settings that include:
3a. Flock networks shared with me
3b. Networks that I’m sharing

Please provide records in their original electronic, machine readable format. For example, please provide csv or spreadsheet files where applicable. Please do not redirect me to your transparency portal.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Rose Terse

This letter is to clarify what information you are seeking from the Tukwila Police Department. 
When I conducted the search to fulfill item 2 of your request, the results for Dec 1 and Dec 2, 2024 were over 17,000 lines of data.  Can you please confirm this is what you want, or, if you would like to narrow your search to better get what you are looking for?  I am happy to talk over the phone if that helps us determine what you need most. 
If you would like the department to proceed with your public information request, please provide clarifications within thirty (30) days from 05/19/2025.  Otherwise, the Tukwila Police Department will continue this portion of the request as you first described it. 
You may provide a response to the department by any of the following methods:  
  * Via the Tukwila PD electronic Record Center; or

communications.subject: Public Records Request :: P032248-051525
communications.communication:
RE: PUBLIC RECORDS REQUEST of May 15, 2025, Reference # P032248-051525 
Dear Rose  Terse, 
The Tukwila Police Department received a public records request from you on May 15, 2025 via our electronic Records Center. Your request mentioned: 
Thank you for your response.  The data will be in a pdf, as any information related to an open investigation must be redacted. We are already working on the request, but it will take several installments due to the size of the request. "To Whom It May Concern: 

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records: 

Records related to the department’s Flock Safety system: 
1. Organization Audit in Flock. 
The report should include data logged from the period of December 1, 2024, to the date this request is processed. Per Flock's documentation, the Organization Audit is available within the Insights tab and is defined as searches done within the agency. 

2. Network Audit in Flock. 
The report should include data logged from the period of December 1, 2024, to the date this request is processed. Per Flock's documentation, the Network Audit is available within the Insights tab and is defined as searches of the organization’s Flock network by any agency in the Flock System. 

3. A list of network share settings that include: 
3a. Flock networks shared with me 
3b. Networks that I’m sharing 

Please provide records in their original electronic, machine readable format. For example, please provide csv or spreadsheet files where applicable. Please do not redirect me to your transparency portal. 

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes. 

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not. 

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires. 

Sincerely, 

Rose Terse

title: Graffiti Nuisance Notices

communications.subject: Washington Public Records Act Request: Graffiti Nuisance Notices
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

1. The spreadsheet of all graffiti nuisance notices issued by the city since 9/1/24. Please refer to the records you provided in response to my previous request C192645-080824.
2. A copy of the most recent graffiti nuisance notice issued.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Rose Terse

communications.subject: City of Seattle Public Records Request Center - Invoice Ready :: C231564-070625
communications.communication:
Dear Rose Terse, 
 
Records in response to your public disclosure request C231564-070625 received on July 06, 2025 are now available. The cost for the records is as follows: 
 
Invoice Number: INV25-C231564-1 
Total: $1.25 
 
To pay online, please follow these steps: 
 Please note that you will need to disable any pop-up blockers to make a payment using the system. 
 
  * Navigate to the Public Records Request Center. 
  * Select 'My Records Request Center'. 
  * Select 'View My Requests'. You may be asked to login. 
  * Find this request: C231564-070625. 
  * Select the 'View Invoices' button. 
 
  * Opens a pop-up window showing your invoice: INV25-C231564-1. 
  * Click on the invoice and then the 'Pay Now' button. 
  * Continue processing your payment. 
  * Select 'Done'. 
  * Once the payment process is done, you are returned to the Public Records Request Center. 
  * After your payment is successful you will receive an email from our payments center. 
Once your payment has been approved, we will send you an email with instructions on how to download your records. Note that City staff must manually upload records. Records will be available one to two business days after payment. 
 
Please let your public disclosure officer (PDO) know if you are unable to pay online; your PDO will work with you on alternative ways to make your payment. 
 
You have 30 days from today's date to pay for your records. If the City does not receive your payment within this time period, your request will be considered abandoned, and you will need to submit a new request. 
 Please add seattle@mycusthelp.net to your E-mail contacts/address book to ensure delivery of the record center E-mails to your Inbox. (mailto:seattle@mycusthelp.net) 
This is an auto-generated email and has originated from an unmonitored email account. Please DO NOT REPLY.

title: Richard Bast

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Richard Bast
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

All documents on, about, mentioning, or concerning the private investigator Richard Lee Bast (October 18, 1932 - March 21, 2001), Social Security No. 578-40-9899 and the companies he founded in the greater Washington, DC area known as Redex Corporation (1970s) and International Investigations, Inc. (1980-90s). 

I understand that the file may be rather large. If it exceeds 5,000 pages, I wish to speak to a negotiator to help reduce the scope of responsive records.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Emma Best

communications.communication:
This message is to notify you of a new appeal submission to the FOIAonline application. Appeal information is as follows: 
  * Appeal Tracking Number: DOJ-AP-2019-001059 
  * Request Tracking Number: 1411474 
  * Requester Name: Emma Best 
  * Date Submitted: 11/14/2018 
  * Appeal Status: Submitted 
  * Description:					FBI Appeal

communications.subject: FOIA request 1411473(Redex Corp)
communications.communication:
Good morning Ms. Best,

We're contacting you about the FOIA request you made for records concerning Redex Corp. The FBI has located approximately 2948 pages that are potentially responsive to your request. Requests are processed in the order in which they are received through our multi-track processing system, and the FBI receives a voluminous amount of requests on a daily, weekly, monthly, and annual basis.  Requests are divided into two primary tracks--simple (under 50 pages of potentially responsive documents) and complex (over 50 pages of potentially responsive documents).  Complex requests are further divided into medium (51-950 pages), large (951-8000 pages), and extra-large (over 8000 pages) sub-tracks based upon request size. 

Simple track requests typically require the least amount of time to process.  The more potentially responsive pages a request has, the more complex it becomes, greatly increasing the time required for processing.  Generally, the larger the file, the longer it takes to process. A review of your request determined that it is currently in the complex request large processing track.  Given our current workload and staffing levels, it may yet be a long time before you begin to receive material from this request.   

Reducing the scope of your request may accelerate the processing and allow for a more timely receipt of the information you seek, as it could potentially place your request into a smaller, faster processing track.  This may also reduce duplication costs, if applicable.  Would you be willing to consider reducing the scope of your request?  If so, I would be happy to help you to decide the best approach to take.  We could potentially narrow your request by date, or if you are looking for something specific, we could approach the scope reduction process in that way.

Please let us know if you would like to potentially reduce the scope of your request.  We can be reached via email at fbi.foipa.negotiation@fbi.gov, or you may call 540-868-1695, Monday - Friday between the hours of 7:00am and 3:00pm Eastern time.

Best regards,

FOIA Negotiation Team
FBI Information Management Division
540-868-1695

Need a status check? Contact FOIPA Questions (foipaquestions@fbi.gov).

communications.subject: FW: FOIA request 1411473(Redex Corp)
communications.communication:
Good morning Ms. Bets,

We hadn't heard back from you and just wanted to follow up.

Best regards,

FOIA Negotiation Team
FBI Information Management Division
540-868-1695

Need a status check? Contact FOIPA Questions (foipaquestions@fbi.gov).

communications.subject: FOIPA # 1411474
communications.communication:
Good Afternoon Ms. Best,

We're contacting you about the FOIA request you made for records concerning Richard Bast.  The FBI located approximately 3,144 pages that are potentially responsive to your request.  Requests are processed in the order in which they are received through our multi-track processing system, and the FBI receives a voluminous amount of requests on a daily, weekly, monthly, and annual basis.  Requests are divided into two primary tracks--simple (under 50 pages of potentially responsive documents) and complex (over 50 pages of potentially responsive documents).  Complex requests are further divided into medium (51-950 pages), large (951-8000 pages), and extra-large (over 8000 pages) sub-tracks based upon request size. 

Simple track requests typically require the least amount of time to process.  The more potentially responsive pages a request has, the more complex it becomes, greatly increasing the time required for processing.  Generally, the larger the file, the longer it takes to process.  A review of your request determined that it is currently in the complex request large processing track.  Given our current workload and staffing levels, it may yet be a long time before you begin to receive material from this request.   

Reducing the scope of your request may accelerate the processing and allow for a more timely receipt of the information you seek, as it could potentially place your request into a smaller, faster processing track.  This may also reduce duplication costs, if applicable.  Would you be willing to consider reducing the scope of your request?  If so, we would be happy to help you to decide the best approach to take.  If you are looking for something specific, we could approach the scope reduction process in that way.

The current average time to complete a large track request is approximately 56 months. 

Please let us know if you would like to potentially reduce the scope of your request.  If you reduce the size, you can request the additional records with a new FOIA request upon completion of this one. 

We can be reached via email at fbi.foipa.negotiation@fbi.gov, or you may call 540-868-4894.  We appreciate your patience and hope to hear from you soon.


Sincerely,



Negotiation Team

title: USGS communications

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: USGS communications
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

All communications that include the term "Gulf of America" or "renaming the Gulf of Mexico".

This should include–but not be limited to—emails, notes, memoranda and presentations between USGS staff and between USGS staff and external third parties.

Please include all documentation within the period January 1, 2024 to January 22, 2025, inclusive.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Matt Reynolds

communications.communication:
Dear Mr. Reynolds:

On January 24, 2025, the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) FOIA office received your FOIA request and assigned it control number DOI-2025-03235.  Please cite this number in any future communications with our office regarding your request.  You request the following information:

All communications that include the term "Gulf of America" or "renaming the Gulf of Mexico".

This should include–but not be limited to—emails, notes, memoranda and presentations between USGS staff and between USGS staff and external third parties.

Please include all documentation within the period January 1, 2024 to January 22, 2025, inclusive.

On January 21, 2025, the USGS FOIA office received a similar FOIA request from Mr. Dave Levinthal, assigned control number DOI-2025-003169, for the following information:

Request disclosure from the Office of the Director, Office of Communications and Publishing, U.S. Board on Geographic Names, Office of the Alaska Regional Director, and Office of the Southeast Regional Director.

1. Any records and documents — including but not limited to emails, memoranda, notes, electronic chat messages and calendar items — that include any of the following words/names in either uppercase or lowercase form on changing the name:

• Gulf of Mexico to Gulf of America
• Denali to Mt. McKinley or Mount McKinley

2. The same types of records on purchase of Greenland

The date range for this request is January 1, 2025, to the present.

On January 21, 2025, the USGS FOIA office received a similar FOIA request from Bloomberg News, assigned control number DOI-2025-003184, for the following information:

Request disclosure from the US Geological Survey's U.S. Board on Geographic Names

1) All records, which includes, but is not limited to emails (including attachments), text messages, internal studies, final reports, directives, memos, letters, on changing the name of the Gulf of Mexico the "Gulf of America."

2)The same types of records on changing the name of Denali to "Mount McKinley."

3) Emails (including attachments) of U.S. Board on Geographic Names staff that mention "Gulf of America"

4) Emails of U.S. Board on Geographic Names staff that mention Denali or Mount McKinley.

The timeframe for this request is January 1, 2025 to the present.

Additionally, on January 22, 2025, the USGS FOIA office received a similar FOIA request from WIRED, assigned control number DOI-2025-003203, for the following information:

Records dated from December 1, 2024 through the time this request is processed relating to Donald Trump's desire to rename the Gulf of Mexico as the Gulf of America and the related executive order and in the possession of Michael Tischler, Shellie Zahniser, or Chris Hammond of the U.S. Geological Survey.  The term “records” includes emails (with attachments) but also refers to other documents and items, such as text messages; invitations, communications, and chats from meeting applications such as Zoom and Microsoft Teams; encrypted apps such as Signal, WhatsApp, and others; phone records; calendar entries; recordings of virtual or in-person meetings; and communications on collaboration platforms such as Slack. It omits news articles and messages from listservs that distribute them unless accompanied by substantial commentary from one of the above-named people or an interlocutor.

Your request falls into the Complex processing track.  We have gathered materials as potentially responsive to DOI-2025-003169, DOI-2025-003184, and DOI-2025-003203.  However, we have not yet completed a review of these records.  We will provide records in rolling releases to you in conjunction with releases issue for DOI-2025-003169, DOI-2025-003184, and DOI-2025-003203.

We classified you as an “other use” requester.  As such, we may charge you for some of our search and duplication costs, but we will not charge you for our review costs; you are also entitled to up to 2 hours of search time and 100 pages of photocopies (or an equivalent volume) for free.  See 43 C.F.R. § 2.39.  If, after taking into consideration your fee category entitlements, our processing costs are less than $50.00, we will not bill you because the cost of collection would be greater than the fee collected.  See 43 C.F.R. § 2.49(a)(1).  We do not anticipate any fees related to your request.

The 2007 FOIA amendments created the Office of Government Information Services (OGIS) to offer mediation services to resolve disputes between FOIA requesters and Federal agencies as a non-exclusive alternative to litigation.  Using OGIS services does not affect your right to pursue litigation.  You may contact OGIS in any of the following ways:

Office of Government Information Services
National Archives and Records Administration
8601 Adelphi Road – OGIS
College Park, Maryland  20740-6001
Telephone:     (202) 741-5770
Fax:                 (202) 741-5769
Toll-free:         1-877-684-6448
E-mail:            ogis@nara.gov<mailto:ogis@nara.gov>
Web:                https://www.archives.gov/ogis

Please note that using OGIS services does not affect the timing of filing an appeal with the Department’s FOIA & Privacy Act Appeals Officer.  Contact information for the Department’s FOIA Public Liaison, who you may also seek dispute resolution services from, is available at https://www.doi.gov/foia/foiacenters.

If you have any questions, please contact me by email at jcearley@usgs.gov<mailto:jcearley@usgs.gov>.




Sincerely,

Judy Cearley

Government Information Specialist

U.S. Geological Survey

Department of the Interior

(650) 329-4035 (office)

foia@usgs.gov<mailto:foia@usgs.gov>

communications.subject: FOIA: DOI-USGS-2025-003235 - Delayed Processing Notification
communications.communication:
Dear Mr. Reynolds,

We are writing regarding your FOIA request, DOI-USGS-2025-003235, to provide delayed processing notification.

As yet, we have been unable to make a determination on your request, but we do intend to comply with your request.  Your request falls into the Complex processing track, there are 11 requests pending ahead of yours in our processing queue.

At this time, we are actively working on your request.  We have completed the preliminary review of the potentially responsive records.  We are preparing an interim release to you and have sent the records for an internal review.  We anticipate providing the interim release to you by March 17, 2025.

Due to the nature of the remaining records, consultations have been sent to other federal agencies, and we are waiting for their responses.  Once we receive responses from the other federal agencies, the records will still need to go through legal review by the Department of the Interior, Office of the Solicitor, Division of General Law.

We apologize for this delay.  You may narrow the scope of your request to obtain quicker processing in your currently assigned track or move the request into a different track (which may have the effect of reducing the cost of processing your request and having it processed more quickly).  You also may agree to an alternative time period for processing by communicating with us, our FOIA Requester Center, or the FOIA Public Liaison.  Contact information for the Department’s FOIA Requester Centers and FOIA Public Liaison is available at https://www.doi.gov/foia/foiacenters.

You may also seek dispute resolution services from the Office of Government Information Services (OGIS).  If you choose to contact OGIS, you may do so in any of the following ways:

Office of Government Information Services
National Archives and Records Administration
8601 Adelphi Road – OGIS
College Park, Maryland  20740-6001
Telephone:      (202) 741-5770
Toll-free:         1-877-684-6448
E-mail:            ogis@nara.gov<mailto:ogis@nara.gov>
Web:                https://ogis.archives.gov<https://ogis.archives.gov/>

You may file an appeal with the Department’s FOIA/Privacy Act Appeals Officer regarding this delay.  If you choose to appeal this delay, you may do so anytime between now and the date we make our determination on the FOIA request.  Appeals arriving or delivered after 5 p.m. Eastern Time, Monday through Friday, will be deemed received on the next workday.

Your appeal must be made in writing.  You may submit your appeal and accompanying materials to the FOIA/Privacy Act Appeals Officer by mail, courier service, fax, or email.  All communications concerning your appeal should be clearly marked with the words: "FREEDOM OF INFORMATION APPEAL."  You must also include with your appeal copies of all correspondence between you and USGS concerning your FOIA request, including your original FOIA request and USGS's response.  Failure to include with your appeal all correspondence between you and USGS will result in the Department's rejection of your appeal, unless the FOIA/Privacy Act Appeals Officer determines (in the FOIA/Privacy Act Appeals Officer’s sole discretion) that good cause exists to accept the defective appeal.

Please include your name and daytime telephone number (or the name and telephone number of an appropriate contact), email address and fax number (if available) in case the FOIA/Privacy Act Appeals Officer needs additional information or clarification of your appeal.

DOI FOIA/Privacy Act Appeals Office Contact Information
Department of the Interior
Office of the Solicitor
Attn: FOIA/Privacy Act Appeals Office
1849 C Street, N.W.
MS-6556 MIB
Washington, DC  20240
Telephone:      (202) 208-5339
Fax:                 (202) 208-6677
Email:              FOIA.Appeals@sol.doi.gov<https://mail.google.com/mail/?view=cm&fs=1&tf=1&to=FOIA.Appeals@sol.doi.gov>

For more information on FOIA Administrative Appeals, you may review the Department's FOIA regulations at 43 C.F.R. Part 2, Subpart H<https://www.ecfr.gov/current/title-43/part-2#subpart-H>.<http://www.ecfr.gov/cgi-bin/text-idx?c=ecfr&sid=0fc3ab3499768eebc2e3691c8cf88dec&rgn=div5&view=text&node=43:1.1.1.1.2&idno=43#43:1.1.1.1.2.8>

We regret the delay and appreciate your consideration.  If you have any questions, please contact me by email at foia@usgs.gov<mailto:foia@usgs.gov>.

Thank you for your patience while we continue processing your request.




Sincerely,

Judy Cearley

Government Information Specialist

U.S. Geological Survey

Department of the Interior

(650) 329-4035 (office)

foia@usgs.gov<mailto:foia@usgs.gov>

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Texas Public Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

I would like a spreadsheet containing all the academic dishonesty reports from the beginning of the Fall 2021 semester to the end of the Spring 2025 Semester, organized by university college.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Anonymous

title: Request for Correctional Mental Health Staff Directory and Contact Information (D.C. Department of Corrections)

communications.subject: DC Freedom of Information Act Request: Request for Correctional Mental Health Staff Directory and Contact Information (D.C. Department of Corrections)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the DC Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

I am requesting a list of currently employed mental health professionals within your state's Department of Corrections or its subsidiary agencies, as well as their contact information.

Specifically, I am requesting:

- Full names
- Job titles
- Assigned correctional facility
- Government-issued email addresses
- Government-issued phone numbers (direct desk numbers if available, otherwise department phone numbers with or without extensions)
- Department/division (e.g. Behavioral Health, Mental Health Services)

This request applies to the following roles: rehabilitative program coordinators, licensed psychologists, psychiatrists, clinical social workers, and other licensed mental health professionals serving incarcerated populations in state-operated facilities.

If available, I request this information be provided in a machine-readable format such as CSV or Excel.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 15 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Andrew Ma

communications.communication:
Dear MuckRock News: 
Thank you for your interest in public records of District of Columbia. Your request has been received and is being processed. Your request was received in this office on 6/11/2025 and given the reference number R011574-061125 for tracking purposes. 
In all future correspondence regarding this request, please reference request number R011574-061125. You can monitor the progress of your request in the " My Records Center". (https://u8387778.ct.sendgrid.net/ls/click?upn=u001.VEsWrlMiJDg0mXafq1mEXcOhwwBPGHifqhO6OQOqgdwS-2FNpGxLbyeC-2FXmT4cIxy2lH6u_B-2FefHXMqqa3-2BMeO3armGlK19P1MtxST266YUwqBM8MOm-2FXhmDarTSxE4Is9KhDiwE40eBzdhG2MLN-2Bk-2B8iL7Q44Tm7XKhivihC6EX6MMTNS5cupEyvS5S8uYBWzMuBCNVAJXg-2Fl-2B0QHK8S3WtJXIXd65z3J9gHcjR1jM7NdMGdkhvMJYSq2bzdrTaCPkS2qCWUStx-2BV1Z4RSQol4XF5UAIcacGnwFAe5fxkLtBwFLnUS38nQXf-2Bm315r5V0s0Cfo7F-2FTwbo9omtbi8pSAvAVVyZOkf2MW74BnmMnglvDjxCve4NDTg6Vo-2BX0kVZ1HB1piQmlQwMUCNv1GWpT7VF-2BTQ0nfDG0JJOkeZ99qrQygMeUYQa6WJnYGaDH81bUODDJ) 
 
The District of Columbia is required to respond to your FOIA request within fifteen (15) business days of its receipt.  See D.C. Official Code § 2-532(c)(2011).  However, under certain circumstances, D.C. Official Code § 2-532(d)(2011) authorizes the District to extend, by ten (10) additional days, the deadline by which it must respond to a FOIA request.  One of the circumstances provided by that statute is a case in which the District needs additional time to search for, collect and examine voluminous amounts of records and/or consult with an additional D.C. agency. 
For any questions regarding your request, please contact the FOIA office directly. Find the list of agency Open Government and FOIA contact information by visiting FOIA Contact Information. For ease of reference, we ask that you have your FOIA Reference Number available when you contact the FOIA office. 
Regards, 
District of Columbia 
To monitor the progress or update this request please log into the DC FOIA Center (https://u8387778.ct.sendgrid.net/ls/click?upn=u001.VEsWrlMiJDg0mXafq1mEXcOhwwBPGHifqhO6OQOqgdxw4Mq-2FzcQk7O8GiIWvvoHaFe7dwUbT3XILFbXayco3OHANGC-2BQPP9LKzK-2FS0mkS98-3DfwTD_B-2FefHXMqqa3-2BMeO3armGlK19P1MtxST266YUwqBM8MOm-2FXhmDarTSxE4Is9KhDiwE40eBzdhG2MLN-2Bk-2B8iL7Q44Tm7XKhivihC6EX6MMTNS5cupEyvS5S8uYBWzMuBCNVAJXg-2Fl-2B0QHK8S3WtJXIXd65z3J9gHcjR1jM7NdMGdkhvMJYSq2bzdrTaCPkS2qCWUStx-2BV1Z4RSQol4XF5UAIcacGnwFAe5fxkLtBwFLnUS38nQXf-2Bm315r5V0s0CfoPcSk1WMzFuVxZy3JlZY7uv-2BtMKExqWJ-2FCEK1Hz0c4-2FQN-2FJbDhplHp7o-2Fa7jgoVQRDX51aypZyQdSgmHFHRSmMPntFU5dtMzADZY5iSv61igEk1sODXC21QmWWhHLX-2BVS)

communications.subject: RE: DC Freedom of Information Act Request: Request for Correctional Mental Health Staff Directory and Contact Information (D.C. Department of Corrections)
communications.communication:
Andrew Ma
MuckRock News
DEPT MR 186573
263 Huntington Ave
Boston, MA 02115

Dear Mr. Ma,

This is the response of the DC Department of Corrections (DOC) to your below FOIA request, seeking “a list of currently employed mental health professionals” serving the inmates that are in DOC’s custody. Please be advised that a contractor, Unity Health Care, Inc., provides health care services to DOC inmates. The information you are requesting relates to the contractor’s personnel matter. It is not the kind of information that DOC creates and maintains. Under the FOIA, an agency’s search obligation is limited to records or information the agency has created and/or maintained. Finally, DOC did not create and did not find the requested list.

If you consider this response a denial of your FOIA request, please be advised that, under D.C. Official Code § 2-537 and 1 DCMR 412, you may appeal to the Mayor or to the Superior Court of the District of Columbia.

If you elect to appeal to the Mayor, your appeal must be in writing and contain “Freedom of Information Act Appeal” or “FOIA Appeal” in the subject line of the letter as well as on the outside of the envelope.  The appeal must include (1) a copy of the original request, (2) a copy of this letter, (3) a statement of the circumstances, reasons, and or arguments advanced in support of disclosure, and (4) a daytime telephone number, and e-mail and/or U.S. Mail address at which you can be reached.  The appeal must be emailed to foia.appeals@dc.gov<mailto:foia.appeals@dc.gov> or mailed to the Mayor’s Office of Legal Counsel (MOLC) at 1350 Pennsylvania Avenue, N.W., Suite 407, Washington, D.C. 20004. Further, a copy of all appeal materials must be forwarded to me.

Failure to follow these administrative steps will result in delay in the processing and commencement of a response to your appeal to the Mayor.

Sincerely,

Oluwasegun Obebe
Records, Information & Privacy Officer
DC Department of Corrections
Office of the General Counsel
3924 Minnesota Ave, NE
Washington, DC 20019
(202) 671-2055 (O)
(202) 538-2389 (C)
(202) 671-1705 (F)
Segun.obebe@dc.gov<mailto:Segun.obebe@dc.gov>
www.doc.dc.gov<http://www.doc.dc.gov/>
[cid:image003.jpg@01DBDADE.CB5B3A30]

communications.subject: RE: DC Freedom of Information Act Request: Request for Correctional Mental Health Staff Directory and Contact Information (D.C. Department of Corrections)
communications.communication:
Dear Mr. Obebe,

Thank you again for your response and for clarifying that mental health services are provided by Unity Health Care.

In light of that, I’d like to respectfully follow up with two related requests:
	1.	Chaplaincy Contacts: Could the DC Department of Corrections provide a list of currently employed or contracted chaplains or staff involved in spiritual or faith-based programming within DOC-operated facilities? Specifically, I’m looking for:
	•	Full names
	•	Job titles
	•	Assigned facility
	•	Government-issued work email (or phone number if email is not available)
	2.	Unity Health Care Liaison: I understand that DOC does not maintain personnel records for Unity Health Care. That said, would it be possible to share contact information for a point of contact at Unity Health Care — ideally someone in a supervisory or coordination role — who oversees behavioral or mental health programming in DOC facilities? If you do not have this directly on file, any guidance or direction would be appreciated.

To provide some context: I represent a grassroots meditation group that offers free, trauma-informed mindfulness programs to support the well-being of incarcerated individuals. We’re hoping to connect with relevant stakeholders — including chaplains and behavioral health coordinators — to understand whether our offerings might be supportive within existing wellness or rehabilitative programming.

Thank you again for your time and consideration.

Warm regards,
Andrew Ma

communications.subject: RE: DC Freedom of Information Act Request: Request for Correctional Mental Health Staff Directory and Contact Information (D.C. Department of Corrections)
communications.communication:
Dear Mr. Obebe,

Thank you again for your response and for clarifying that mental health services are provided by Unity Health Care.

In light of that, I’d like to respectfully follow up with two related requests:
1. Chaplaincy Contacts: Could the DC Department of Corrections provide a list of currently employed or contracted chaplains or staff involved in spiritual or faith-based programming within DOC-operated facilities? Specifically, I’m looking for:
• Full names
• Job titles
• Assigned facility
• Government-issued work email (or phone number if email is not available)
2. Unity Health Care Liaison: I understand that DOC does not maintain personnel records for Unity Health Care. That said, would it be possible to share contact information for a point of contact at Unity Health Care — ideally someone in a supervisory or coordination role — who oversees behavioral or mental health programming in DOC facilities? If you do not have this directly on file, any guidance or direction would be appreciated.

To provide some context: I represent a grassroots meditation group that offers free, trauma-informed mindfulness programs to support the well-being of incarcerated individuals. We’re hoping to connect with relevant stakeholders — including chaplains and behavioral health coordinators — to understand whether our offerings might be supportive within existing wellness or rehabilitative programming.

Thank you again for your time and consideration.

Warm regards,
Andrew Ma

title: Flock Safety search audits, network sharing, and general order (Bonney Lake Police Department)

communications.subject: Washington Public Records Act Request: Flock Safety search audits, network sharing, and general order (Bonney Lake Police Department)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Records related to the department’s Flock Safety system:
1. Organization Audit in Flock. 
The report should include data logged from the period of December 1, 2024, to the date this request is processed. Per Flock's documentation, the Organization Audit is available within the Insights tab and is defined as searches done within the agency.

2. Network Audit in Flock.
The report should include data logged from the period of December 1, 2024, to the date this request is processed. Per Flock's documentation, the Network Audit is available within the Insights tab and is defined as searches of the organization’s Flock network by any agency in the Flock System.

3. A list of network share settings that include:
3a. Flock networks shared with me
3b. Networks that I’m sharing

Please provide records in their original electronic, machine readable format. For example, please provide csv or spreadsheet files where applicable. Please do not redirect me to your transparency portal.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Rose Terse

communications.subject: Public Records Request
communications.communication:
Good morning,

Request number: 20250612-RT1

We received your request for FLOCK records. We have located responsive records for items 1, 3a and 3b. The scope of records for item 2 would be very large and creating a record that we do not have. Pursuant to per WAC 44-14-04003(6)<https://app.leg.wa.gov/wac/default.aspx?cite=44-14-04003>, we are not obligated to create a record in order to fulfill this request:

(6) No duty to create records. An agency is not obligated to create a new record to satisfy a records request. However, sometimes it is easier for an agency to create a record responsive to the request rather than collecting and making available voluminous records that contain small pieces of the information sought by the requestor or find itself in a controversy about whether the request requires the creation of a new record. The decision to create a new record is left to the discretion of the agency. With respect to databases, for example, there is not always a simple dichotomy between producing an existing record and creating a new record. In addition, an agency may decide to provide a customized service and if so, assess a customized service charge for the actual costs of staff technology expertise needed to prepare data compilations, or when such customized access services are not used by the agency for other business purposes.

However, if you wish to receive the records responsive to items 1, 3a and 3b there is a fee of $3.50. I have attached the worksheet for how the fee was calculated based off the fact that necessary redactions will be applied to some documents. Please call the main line below during normal business hours Mon-Fri 8:30-4:30) to pay your fee. We will be closed tomorrow, 6/19.

If we do not receive payment by 6/27/25 your request will be considered abandoned and closed.

Thank you,

[cid:image002.png@01DBE033.AC1569C0]
Miranda Jeter
Records Clerk
Bonney Lake Police Department

communications.subject: Public Records Act Response – Closing Letter
communications.communication:
Dear Rose Terse,

Request number: 20250612-RT1

This letter is to inform you I have enclosed all records in response to your public records request which you made on 6/12/25 for a copy of “Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:
Records related to the department's Flock Safety system:
1. Organization Audit in Flock.
The report should include data logged from the period of Decemebr 1, 2024, to the date this request is processed. Per Flock's documentation, the Organization Audit is available within the Insights tab and is defined as searches done within the ageny.
2. Network Audit in Flock.
The report should inlude data logged from the period of December 1, 2024, to the date this request is processed. Per Flock's documentation, the Network Audit is avialble within the Insights tab and is defined as searches of the organization's Flock network by any agency in the Flock system.
3. A list of network share settings that include:
3a. Flock networks shared with me
3b. Networks that I'm sharing
Please provide records in their original electronic, machine readable format. For example, please provide csv or spreadsheet files where applicable. Please do not redirect me to your transparency portal.
The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.
In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.
Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.”

Please note that some records have either been withheld in their entirety or redacted based on a statutory exemption. For any records that may be denied, you do have the right to seek internal review of any denials of requests per RCW 42.56.520(4).<https://app.leg.wa.gov/RCW/default.aspx?cite=42.56.520> The enclosed exemption log provides information about the records withheld and/or redacted and the basis for withholding or redaction.

Your records request is considered fulfilled and, therefore, is now closed. The one-year statute of limitations to seek judicial review has started.

This concludes the City of Bonney Lake’s response to your public disclosure request; your request is now closed. If you believe that the City of Bonney Lake has other records that are responsive to this request, or if you have questions or difficulty viewing the records provided, please contact me within 14 days.

Please contact the office at (253) 863-2218 opt 4, fax (253) 863-2661 or by email pdrecords@cobl.us<mailto:pdrecords@cobl.us> if you need further assistance.

Thank you,

[cid:image006.png@01DBF57A.63913EC0]
Miranda Jeter
Records Clerk
Bonney Lake Police Department
